name: adaptive temperature
info: # Adaptive Temperature Control Algorithm This documentation describes an adaptive temperature control algorithm designed for systems that monitor and control two temperature readingsâ€”one slow-responding (e.g., a vessel's internal temperature) and one fast-responding (e.g., ambient or external temperature). The algorithm calculates a weighted average of these temperatures, dynamically adjusting the weighting to avoid overshoot while ensuring timely responses to temperature changes. ## Inputs The node accepts two kinds of input. Either you pass in an object as payload in which case the node will read any of `payload.t1`, `payload.t2` and `payload.target`/`payload.tset` that exists. Or, you can alternatively set `msg.topic` to any of `t1`, `t2` or `target`/`tset` and pass the value as `payload`. As you can see, the target temperature can be provided either as `target` or `tset`. The node will accept both. In the remainder of this documentation, that value is refered to as ğ‘‡set. ## Outputs * payload: The adjusted combined temperature of ğ‘‡1 and ğ‘‡2, that should be passed as temperature reading to the thermostat. * t1: The latest ğ‘‡1 value * t2: The latest ğ‘‡2 value * target: The desired target temperature. Can be useful as pass-through to directly provide to the thermostat. ## Purpose and Use Case When controlling a temperature-sensitive system, especially in cases where you have a more sluggish (slow-responding) internal temperature sensor and a faster-responding external sensor, there's often a risk of overshooting the internal temperature. This happens when the external environment is heated or cooled too quickly while the internal temperature lags behind. By dynamically adjusting the weight between the two temperature readings based on how close the internal temperature is to the setpoint, this algorithm helps: * Prevent temperature overshoot by smoothly transitioning control focus from the faster external temperature to the more sluggish internal temperature. * Enhance response time by leveraging the faster-responding temperature reading when the internal temperature is far from the target. * Provide balanced control in systems with different temperature dynamics for internal and external environments. ## How the Algorithm Works The algorithm combines two temperature readings, ğ‘‡1 (internal) and ğ‘‡2 (external), and dynamically adjusts the weight assigned to each, with a focus on minimizing overshoot. The weight is determined by a function that changes based on how close the internal temperature is to the target setpoint ğ‘‡set. ### Key Formula The algorithm is as follows: Where: * ğ›¼(ğ‘‡1,ğ‘‡set) is the dynamic weighting factor and determines how much weight is given to the internal temperature ğ‘‡1. ## Parameters The following parameters affects how the combined temperature is calculated and can be changed in the node configuration. The default values serve as a good starting point. * baseline: Defaults to 0.65. A parameter that determines the minimum influence of ğ‘‡1 in the calculation. A baseline of 0.5 means that ğ‘‡1 will always have at least a 50% influence, even when the internal temperature is far from the setpoint. * beta (ğ›½): Defaults to 0.5. A steepness parameter that controls how quickly the algorithm shifts from relying on ğ‘‡2 to relying on ğ‘‡1. A higher ğ›½ value makes the transition sharper, while a lower ğ›½ value smooths the transition. * delta (Î”ğ‘‡): Defaults to 3.5. A threshold value that controls how close ğ‘‡1 needs to be to the setpoint before the algorithm starts prioritizing it over ğ‘‡2. A smaller Î”ğ‘‡ value means the algorithm will start focusing on ğ‘‡1 only when it's very close to the setpoint, while a larger Î”ğ‘‡ will cause the system to prioritize ğ‘‡1 earlier. ### Effects of Adjusting Parameters 1. Baseline: * Higher baseline (e.g., 0.6â€“0.7): Ensures that ğ‘‡1 (the internal temperature) has a higher influence on the combined temperature, even when it's far from the setpoint. This could result in slower system response but minimizes the risk of overshooting the target. * Lower baseline (e.g., 0.3â€“0.4): Allows ğ‘‡2 to have more influence when ğ‘‡1 is far from the setpoint, resulting in a faster response to temperature changes, but potentially increasing the risk of overshoot. 2. Beta: * Higher ğ›½ (e.g., 5-10): Causes a rapid shift from relying on ğ‘‡2 to ğ‘‡1 as ğ‘‡1 nears the setpoint. This makes the system more sensitive to changes in ğ‘‡1 as it approaches the target but could lead to less smooth control. * Lower ğ›½ (e.g., 1-3): Results in a smoother transition, making the system less responsive to sudden changes but providing more stable control. 3. Delta T: * Larger Î”ğ‘‡ (e.g., 2-3Â°C): The system will begin prioritizing ğ‘‡1 earlier, when it's still relatively far from the setpoint. This reduces the risk of overshooting but may make the system slower to reach the desired temperature. * Smaller Î”ğ‘‡ (e.g., 0.5-1Â°C): The system will rely on ğ‘‡2 for longer, only prioritizing ğ‘‡1 when it's very close to the setpoint. This makes the system more responsive but can lead to overshoot if ğ‘‡1 lags behind significantly. ### Example Use Case Imagine you are controlling the temperature of a fermentation vessel inside a climate-controlled cabinet. The internal temperature of the liquid (ğ‘‡1) is slow to change, while the cabinet's air temperature (ğ‘‡2) can change more rapidly. Using this algorithm, you can: * Allow the external air temperature (ğ‘‡2) to influence the control system when the liquid temperature is far from the setpoint. * Gradually shift the focus to the liquid temperature (ğ‘‡1) as it nears the desired setpoint, avoiding overshooting the internal temperature. This method ensures smooth, adaptive control, minimizing temperature fluctuations in sensitive environments like fermentation, laboratory experiments, or other temperature-critical applications. ## Appendix ### Latex expressions #### Weighting factor ğ›¼ $$ \alpha(T_1, T_{\text{set}}) = \text{baseline} + (1 - \text{baseline}) \times \frac{1}{1 + e^{-\beta \cdot (\left|T_{\text{set}} - T_1\right| - \Delta T)}} $$ #### Combined temperature $$ T_{\text{combined}} = \alpha(T_1, T_{\text{set}}) \cdot T_1 + \left(1 - \alpha(T_1, T_{\text{set}})\right) \cdot T_2 $$

name: sigmoid
